An Operator Splitting View of Federated Learning

Saber Malekmohammadi1,2 , Kiarash Shaloudegi211footnotemark: 1, Zeou Hu 1,2, Yaoliang Yu1
University of Waterloo, Canada1
{saber.malekmohammadi, zeou.hu, yaoliang.yu}@uwaterloo.ca
Huawei Noahâ€™s Ark Lab, Montreal, Canada2
kiarash.shaloudegi@huawei.com These authors contributed equally to this work
Abstract

Over the past few years, the federated learning (FL) community has witnessed a proliferation of new FL algorithms. However, our understating of the theory of FL is still fragmented, and a thorough, formal comparison of these algorithms remains elusive. Motivated by this gap, we show that many of the existing FL algorithms can be understood from an operator splitting point of view. This unification allows us to compare different algorithms with ease, to refine previous convergence results and to uncover new algorithmic variants. In particular, our analysis reveals the vital role played by the step size in FL algorithms. The unification also leads to a streamlined and economic way to accelerate FL algorithms, without incurring any communication overhead. We perform numerical experiments on both convex and nonconvex models to validate our findings.

1 Introduction

The accompanying (moderate) computational power of modern smart devices such as phones, watches, home appliances, cars, etc., and the enormous data accumulated from their interconnected ecosystem have fostered new opportunities and challenges to train/tailor modern deep models. Federated learning (FL), as a result, has recently emerged as a massively distributed framework that enables training a shared or personalized model without infringing user privacy. Tremendous progress has been made since the seminal work of [1], including algorithmic innovations [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], convergence analysis [9, 10, 11, 12, 13], personalization [14, 15, 16, 17, 18], privacy protection [19, 20], model robustness [21, 22, 23, 24], fairness [25, 26, 27], standardization [28, 29], applications [30], just to name a few. We refer to the excellent surveys [31, 32, 33] and the references therein for the current state of affairs in FL.

The main goal of this work is to take a closer examination of some of the most popular FL algorithms, including FedAvg [1], FedProx [2], and FedSplit [5], by connecting them with the well-established theory of operator splitting in optimization. In particular, we show that FedAvg corresponds to forward-backward splitting and we demonstrate a trade-off in its step size and number of local epochs, while a similar phenomenon has also been observed in [10, 5, 12, 34]. FedProx, on the other hand, belongs to backward-backward splitting, or equivalently, forward-backward splitting on a related but regularized problem, which has been somewhat overlooked in the literature. Interestingly, our results reveal that the recent personalized model in [15] is exactly the problem that FedProx aims to solve. Moreover, we show that when the step size in FedProx diminishes (sublinearly fast), then it actually solves the original problem, which is contrary to the observation in [5] where the step size is fixed and confirms again the importance of step size in FL.

For FedSplit, corresponding to Peaceman-Rachford splitting [35, 36], we show that its convergence (in theory) heavily hinges on the strong convexity of the objective and hence might be less stable for nonconvex problems.

Inspecting FL through the lens of operator splitting also allows us to immediately uncover new FL algorithms, by adapting existing splitting algorithms. Indeed, we show that Douglas-Rachford splitting [37, 36] (more precisely the method of partial inverse [38]) yields a (slightly) slower but more stable variant of FedSplit, while at the same time shares a close connection to FedProx: the latter basically freezes the update of a dual variable in the former. We also propose FedRP by combining the reflector in FedSplit and the projection (averaing) in FedAvg and FedProx, and extend an algorithm of [39]. We improve the convergence analysis of FedRP and empirically demonstrate its competitiveness with other FL algorithms. We believe these results are just the tip of the ice-berg and much more progress can now be expected: the marriage between FL and operator splitting simply opens a range of new possibilities to be explored.

Our holistic view of FL algorithms suggests a very natural unification, building on which we show that the aforementioned algorithms reduce to different parameter settings in a grand scheme. We believe this is an important step towards standardizing FL from an algorithmic point of view, in addition to standard datasets, models and evaluation protocols as already articulated in [28, 29]. Our unification also allows one to compare and implement different FL algorithms with ease, and more importantly to accelerate them in a streamlined and economic fashion. Indeed, for the first time we show that Anderson-acceleration [40, 41], originally proposed for nonlinear fixed-point iteration, can be adapted to accelerate existing FL algorithms and we provide practical implementations that do not incur any communication overhead. We perform experiments on both convex and nonconvex models to validate our findings, and compare the above-mentioned FL algorithms on an equal footing.

We proceed in Â§2 with some background introduction. Our main contributions are presented in Â§3, where we connect FL with operator splitting, shed new insights on existing algorithms, suggest new algorithmic variants and refine convergence analysis, and in Â§4, where we present a unification of current algorithms and propose strategies for further acceleration. We conclude in Â§5 with some future directions. Due to space limit, all proofs are deferred to AppendixÂ C.

3 FL as operator splitting

Following [5], in this section we interpret existing FL algorithms (FedAvg, FedProx, FedSplit) from the operator splitting point of view. We reveal the importance of the step size, obtain new convergence guarantees, and uncover some new and accelerated algorithmic variants.

3.1 FedAvg as forward-backward splitting

The FedAvg algorithm of [1] is essentially a kğ‘˜k-step version of the forward-backward splitting approach of [42]:

ğ—t+1â†ğ–¯Hâ€‹ğ–¦ğ–¿,kÎ·tâ€‹ğ—t,whereğ–¦ğ–¿,kÎ·t:=ğ–¦ğ–¿Î·tâˆ˜ğ–¦ğ–¿Î·tâˆ˜â‹¯âˆ˜ğ–¦ğ–¿Î·tâŸkâ€‹Â timesÂ ,formulae-sequenceâ†subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ–¯ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–¿ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡whereassignsuperscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–¿ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptâŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘˜Â timesÂ \displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}\leftarrow\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f},k}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathrm{where}\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f},k}^{\eta_{t}}:=\underbrace{\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\circ\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\circ\cdots\circ\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}}_{k\mbox{ times }}, (9)

where we perform kğ‘˜k steps of (forward) gradient updates w.r.t. ğ–¿ğ–¿\mathsf{f} followed by 1 (backward) proximal update w.r.t. Hğ»H. The number of local steps kğ‘˜k turns out to be a key factor: Setting k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 reduces to the usual (stochastic) forward-backward algorithm and enjoys the well-known convergence guarantees. On the other hand, setting k=âˆğ‘˜k=\infty (and assuming convergence on each local function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}) amounts to (repeatedly) averaging the chosen minimizers of fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}â€™s, and eventually converges to the average of minimizers of all mğ‘šm user functions. In general, the performance of the fixed point solution of FedAvg appears to have a dependency on the number of local steps kğ‘˜k and the step size Î·ğœ‚\eta. In particular, when k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, the fixed point does not depend on Î·ğœ‚\eta (as long as it is small enough to guarantee convergence), but for k>1ğ‘˜1k>1, the solution that FedAvg converges to does depend on Î·ğœ‚\eta. Moreover, the final performance is almost completely determined by Î·â€‹(kâˆ’1)ğœ‚ğ‘˜1\eta(k-1) in this quadratic setting when Î·ğœ‚\eta is small, as we verify in experiments, see FigureÂ 2 left (details on generating Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} and ğ›isubscriptğ›ğ‘–\mathbf{b}_{i} can be found in sectionÂ A.1).

FigureÂ 7 in the appendix further illustrates this trade-off where larger local epochs kğ‘˜k and learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta leads to faster convergence (in terms of communication rounds) during the early stages, at the cost of a worse final solution. Similar results are also reported in e.g. [10, 5, 12, 34]. In FigureÂ 2, we run FedAvg in (9) on least squares, logistic regression and a nonconvex CNN on the MNIST dataset [43]. The experiments are run with pre-determined numbers of communication rounds and different configurations of local epochs kğ‘˜k and learning rates Î·ğœ‚\eta. We examine the dependencies of FedAvgâ€™s final performance regarding kğ‘˜k and Î·ğœ‚\eta. We can conclude that, in general, smaller local epochs and learning rates gives better final solutions (assuming sufficient communication rounds to ensure convergence). Moreover, for least squares and logistic regression, the product Î·â€‹(kâˆ’1)ğœ‚ğ‘˜1\eta(k-1) we derived in (11) almost completely determines the final performance, when kğ‘˜k and Î·ğœ‚\eta are within a proper range. For the nonconvex CNN (Fig 2, right), especially with limited communications, the approximation in (11) is too crude to be indicative.

3.2 FedProx as backward-backward splitting

The recent FedProx algorithm [2] replaces the gradient update in FedAvg with a proximal update:

ğ—t+1=ğ–¯Hâ€‹ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹ğ—t,subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ–¯ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}=\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}, (12)

where as before we may use a minibatch to approximate ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿ğœ‚\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta} or select a subset of users to approximate ğ–¯Hsubscriptğ–¯ğ»\mathsf{P}_{H}. Written in this way, it is clear that FedProx is an instantiation of the backward-backward splitting algorithm of [44, 45]. In fact, this algorithm traces back to the early works of e.g. [46, 47, 48], sometimes under the name of the Barycenter method. It was also rediscovered by [49, 50] in the ML community under a somewhat different motivation. [5] pointed out that FedProx does not solve the original problem (1). While technically correct, their conclusion did not take many other subtleties into account, which we explain next.

Following [51], we first note that, with a constant step size Î·tâ‰¡Î·subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‚\eta_{t}\equiv\eta, FedProx is actually equivalent as FedAvg but applied to a â€œregularizedâ€ problem:

minğ—âˆˆHğ–¿~â€‹(ğ—),whereğ–¿~â€‹(ğ—):=âŸ¨ğŸ,ğ–¬ğŸÎ·â€‹(ğ—)âŸ©,Â andÂ â€‹ğ–¬ğŸÎ·â€‹(ğ—)=(ğ–¬f1Î·â€‹(ğ°1),â€¦,ğ–¬fmÎ·â€‹(ğ°m)).formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptğ—ğ»~ğ–¿ğ—where~ğ–¿ğ—1superscriptsubscriptğ–¬ğŸğœ‚ğ—Â andÂ superscriptsubscriptğ–¬ğŸğœ‚ğ—superscriptsubscriptğ–¬subscriptğ‘“1ğœ‚subscriptğ°1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ–¬subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğœ‚subscriptğ°ğ‘š\displaystyle\min_{\mathsf{w}\in H}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \tilde{\mathsf{f}}(\mathsf{w}),\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathrm{where}\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \tilde{\mathsf{f}}(\mathsf{w}):=\left\langle\mathbf{1},\mathsf{M}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})\right\rangle,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mbox{ and }\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathsf{M}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=\big{(}\mathsf{M}_{f_{1}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{1}),\ldots,\mathsf{M}_{f_{m}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{m})\big{)}. (13)

Interestingly, [15] proposed exactly (13) for the purpose of personalization, which we now realize is automatically achieved if we apply FedProx to the original formulation (1). Indeed, âˆ‡ğ–¬ğŸÎ·â€‹(ğ—)=[ğ—âˆ’ğ–¯ğŸÎ·â€‹(ğ—)]/Î·âˆ‡superscriptsubscriptğ–¬ğŸğœ‚ğ—delimited-[]ğ—superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğŸğœ‚ğ—ğœ‚\nabla\mathsf{M}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=[\mathsf{w}-\mathsf{P}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})]/\eta hence ğ–¦f~Î·â€‹(ğ—)=ğ—âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡ğ–¿~â€‹(ğ—)=ğ–¯ğŸÎ·â€‹(ğ—)=(ğ–¯f1Î·â€‹(ğ°1),â€¦,ğ–¯fmÎ·â€‹(ğ°m))superscriptsubscriptğ–¦~ğ‘“ğœ‚ğ—ğ—ğœ‚âˆ‡~ğ–¿ğ—superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğŸğœ‚ğ—superscriptsubscriptğ–¯subscriptğ‘“1ğœ‚subscriptğ°1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ–¯subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğœ‚subscriptğ°ğ‘š\mathsf{G}_{\tilde{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=\mathsf{w}-\eta\nabla\tilde{\mathsf{f}}(\mathsf{w})=\mathsf{P}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=\big{(}\mathsf{P}_{f_{1}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{1}),\ldots,\mathsf{P}_{f_{m}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{m})\big{)}. This simple observation turns out to be crucial in understanding FedProx.

Indeed, a significant challenge in FL is user heterogeneity (a.k.a. non-iid distribution of data), where the individual user functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} may be very different (due to distinct user-specific data). But, we note that333These results are classic and well-known, see e.g. [52]. as Î·â†’0â†’ğœ‚0\eta\to 0, ğ–¬fÎ·â†’fâ†’superscriptsubscriptğ–¬ğ‘“ğœ‚ğ‘“\mathsf{M}_{f}^{\eta}\to f (pointwise or uniformly if fğ‘“f is Lipschitz) while ğ–¬fÎ·â†’minâ¡fâ†’superscriptsubscriptğ–¬ğ‘“ğœ‚ğ‘“\mathsf{M}_{f}^{\eta}\to\min f as Î·â†’âˆâ†’ğœ‚\eta\to\infty. In other words, a larger Î·ğœ‚\eta in (13) â€œsmoothensâ€ heterogeneity in the sense that the functions ğ–¬fiÎ·superscriptsubscriptğ–¬subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ‚\mathsf{M}_{f_{i}}^{\eta} tend to have similar minimizers (while the minimum values may still differ). We are thus motivated to understand the convergence behaviour of FedProx, for small and large Î·ğœ‚\eta, corresponding to the original problem (1) and the smoothened problem, respectively. In fact, we can even adjust Î·ğœ‚\eta dynamically. Below, for simplicity, we assume full gradient (i.e. large batch size) although extensions to stochastic gradient are possible.

Theorem 1.

Assuming each user participates indefinitely, the step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} is bounded from below (i.e. lim inftÎ·t>0subscriptlimit-infimumğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡0\liminf_{t}\eta_{t}>0), the user functions {fi}subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\{f_{i}\} are convex, and homogeneous in the sense that they have a common minimizer, i.e. ğ–¥:=â‹‚iargminğ°ifiâ€‹(ğ°i)â‰ âˆ…assignğ–¥subscriptğ‘–subscriptargminsubscriptğ°ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ°ğ‘–\mathsf{F}:=\bigcap_{i}\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{w}_{i}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\neq\emptyset, then the iterates of FedProx converge to a point in ğ–¥ğ–¥\mathsf{F}, which is a correct solution of (1).

The homogeneity assumption might seem strong since it challenges the necessity of FL in the first place. However, we point out that (a) as a simplified limiting case it does provide insight on when user functions have close minimizers (i.e. homogeneous); (b) by using a large step size Î·ğœ‚\eta FedProx effectively homogenizes the users and its convergence thus follows444The consequence of this must of course be further investigated; see [15] and [2].; (c) modern deep architectures are typically over-parameterized so that achieving null training loss on each user is not uncommon. However, FL is still relevant even in this case since it selects a model that works for every user and hence provides some regularizing effect; (d) even when the homogeneity assumption fails, ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·tsuperscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}} still converges to a point that is in some sense closest to Hğ»H [51].

The next result removes the homogeneity assumption by simply letting step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} diminish:

Theorem 2 ([44, 45]).

Assuming each user participates in every round, the step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} satisfies âˆ‘tÎ·t=âˆsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\sum_{t}\eta_{t}=\infty and âˆ‘tÎ·t2<âˆsubscriptğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2\sum_{t}\eta_{t}^{2}<\infty, and the functions {fi}subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\{f_{i}\} are convex, then the averaged iterates ğ—Â¯t:=âˆ‘s=1tÎ·sâ€‹ğ—sâˆ‘s=1tÎ·sassignsubscriptÂ¯ğ—ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘ subscriptğ—ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘ \bar{\mathsf{w}}_{t}:=\tfrac{\sum_{s=1}^{t}\eta_{s}\mathsf{w}_{s}}{\sum_{s=1}^{t}\eta_{s}} of FedProx converge to a correct solution of the original problem (1).

In AppendixÂ C, we give examples to show the tightness of the step size condition in TheoremÂ 2. We emphasize that ğ—Â¯tsubscriptÂ¯ğ—ğ‘¡\bar{\mathsf{w}}_{t} converges to a solution of the original problem (1), not the regularized problem (13). The subtlety is that we must let the step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} approach 0 reasonably slowly, a possibility that was not discussed in [5] where they always fixed the step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} to a constant Î·ğœ‚\eta. TheoremÂ 2 also makes intuitive sense, as Î·tâ†’0â†’subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡0\eta_{t}\to 0 slowly, we are effectively tracking the solution of the regularized problem (13) which itself tends to the original problem (1): recall that ğ–¬fÎ·â†’fâ†’superscriptsubscriptğ–¬ğ‘“ğœ‚ğ‘“\mathsf{M}_{f}^{\eta}\to f as Î·â†’0â†’ğœ‚0\eta\to 0.

Even the ergodic averaging step in TheoremÂ 2 can be omitted in some cases:

Theorem 3 ([45]).

Under the same assumptions as in TheoremÂ 2, if ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f} is strongly convex or the solution set of (1) has nonempty interior, then the vanilla iterates ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{w}_{t} of FedProx also converge.

We remark that convergence is in fact linear for the second case. Nevertheless, the above two conditions are perhaps not easy to satisfy or verify in most applications. Thus, in practice, we recommend the ergodic averaging in TheoremÂ 2 since it does not create additional overhead (if implemented incrementally) and in our experiments it does not slow down the algorithm noticeably.

There is in fact a quantitative relationship between the original problem (1) and the regularized problem (13), even in the absence of convexity:

Theorem 4 ([50]).

Suppose each fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i}-Lipschitz continuous (and possibly nonconvex), then

âˆ€ğ—,fâ€‹(ğ—)âˆ’f~â€‹(ğ—)â‰¤âˆ‘iÎ»iâ€‹Î·â€‹Mi22.for-allğ—ğ‘“ğ—~ğ‘“ğ—subscriptğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–22\displaystyle\textstyle\forall\mathsf{w},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ f(\mathsf{w})-\tilde{f}(\mathsf{w})\leq\sum_{i}\lambda_{i}\tfrac{\eta M_{i}^{2}}{2}. (14)

Thus, for a small step size Î·ğœ‚\eta, FedProx, aiming to minimize the regularized function ğ–¿~~ğ–¿\tilde{\mathsf{f}} is not quantitatively different from FedAvg that aims at minimizing ğ–¿ğ–¿\mathsf{f}. This again reveals the fundamental importance of step size in FL. We remark that, following the ideas in [50], we may remove the need of ergodic averaging for FedProx if the functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are â€œdefinableâ€ (which most, if not all, functions used in practice are). We omit the technical complication here since the potential gain does not appear to be practically significant.

In FigureÂ 3, we show the effect of step size Î·ğœ‚\eta on the convergence of FedProx, and compare the results with that of FedAvg on both convex and nonconvex models. We run FedProx with both fixed and diminishing step sizes. In the experiments with diminishing step sizes, we have set the initial value of Î·ğœ‚\eta (i.e. Î·0subscriptğœ‚0\eta_{0}) to larger values - compared to the constant Î·ğœ‚\eta values - to ensure that Î·ğœ‚\eta does not get very small after the first few rounds. From the convex experiments (FigÂ 3, left and middle), one can see that FedProx with a fixed learning rate converges fast (in a few hundred rounds) to a suboptimal solution. In contrast, FedProx with diminishing Î·ğœ‚\eta converges slower, but to better quality solutions. It is interesting to note that only when the conditions of TheoremÂ 2 are satisfied (i.e. Î·ğœ‚\eta diminishes neither too fast nor too slow), FedProx converges to a correct solution of the original problem (1), e.g. see the results for Î·tâˆ1/tproportional-tosubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡\eta_{t}\propto 1/t which satisfies both conditions in TheoremÂ 2. Surprisingly, for the nonconvex setting (FigureÂ 3, right), the best results are achieved with larger learning rates. A similar observation about FedAvg in nonconvex settings was reported in [1, Fig. 5 & 6]. 555Note that the results of FedAvg and FedProx for Î·=100ğœ‚100\eta=100 and 100/logâ¡(t)100ğ‘¡100/\log(t) overlap with each other. Moreover, from the results on both convex and nonconvex models, one can see that ergodic averaging does not affect the convergence rate of FedProx noticeably.

3.3 FedSplit as Peaceman-Rachford splitting

[5] introduced the FedSplit algorithm recently:

ğ—t+1=ğ–±Hâ€‹ğ–±ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹ğ—t,subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ–±ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}=\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}, (15)

which is essentially an instantiation of the Peaceman-Rachford splitting algorithm [35, 36]. As shown by [36], FedSplit converges to a correct solution of (1) if ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f} is strictly convex, and the convergence rate is linear if ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f} is strongly convex and smooth (and Î·ğœ‚\eta is small). [5] also studied the convergence behaviour of FedSplit when the reflector ğ–±ğ–¿Î·superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿ğœ‚\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta} is computed approximately. However, we note that convergence behaviour of FedSplit is not known or widely studied for nonconvex problems. In particular, we have the following surprising result:

Theorem 5.

If the reflector ğ–±fÎ·superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ‘“ğœ‚\mathsf{R}_{f}^{\eta} is a (strict) contraction, then fğ‘“f must be strongly convex.

The converse is true if fğ‘“f is also smooth and Î·ğœ‚\eta is small [36, 53]. Therefore, for non-strongly convex or nonconvex problems, we cannot expect FedSplit to converge linearly (if it converges at all).

3.4 FedPi as Douglas-Rachford splitting

A popular alternative to the Peaceman-Rachford splitting is the Douglas-Rachford splitting [37, 36], which, to our best knowledge, has not been applied to the FL setting. The resulting update, which we call FedPi, can be written succinctly as:

ğ—t+1=ğ—t+ğ–±Hâ€‹ğ–±ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹ğ—t2,subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ–±ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}=\tfrac{\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}}{2}, (16)

i.e. we simply average the current iterate and that of FedSplit evenly. Strictly speaking, the above algorithm is a special case of the Douglas-Rachford splitting and was rediscovered by [54] under the name of partial inverse (hence our name FedPi). The moderate averaging step in (16) makes FedPi much more stable:

Theorem 6 ([54, 36]).

Assuming each user participates in every round, the step size Î·tâ‰¡Î·subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‚\eta_{t}\equiv\eta is constant, and the functions {fi}subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\{f_{i}\} are convex, then the vanilla iterates ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{w}_{t} of FedPi converge to a correct solution of the original problem (1).

Compared to FedSplit, FedPi imposes less stringent condition on fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}. However, when fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is indeed strongly convex and smooth, as already noted by [36], FedPi will be slower than FedSplit by a factor close to 22\sqrt{2} (assuming the constant step size is set appropriately for both). More importantly, it may be easier to analyze FedPi on nonconvex functions, as recently demonstrated in [55, 56].

Interestingly, FedPi also has close ties to FedProx. Indeed, this is best seen by expanding the concise formula in (16) and introducing a â€œdual variableâ€ ğ—ğ—\mathsf{u} on the server side666The acute readers may have recognized here the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM). Indeed, the equivalence of ADMM, Douglas-Rachford and partial inverse (under our FL setting) has long been known [[, e.g. ]]Gabay83,EcksteinBertsekas92.:

ğ—“t+1subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{z}_{t+1} â†ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·â€‹(ğ—t+ğ—t)â†absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿ğœ‚subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{u}_{t}) (17)
ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} â†ğ–¯Hâ€‹(ğ—“t+1âˆ’ğ—t)â†absentsubscriptğ–¯ğ»subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}{\color[rgb]{.5,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.5,.5,.5}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{.5}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{.5}-\mathsf{u}_{t}}) (18)
ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{u}_{t+1} â†ğ—t+ğ—t+1âˆ’ğ—“t+1.â†absentsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathsf{u}_{t}+\mathsf{w}_{t+1}-\mathsf{z}_{t+1}. (19)

From the last two updates (18) and (19) it is clear that ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\mathsf{u}_{t+1} is always in HâŸ‚superscriptğ»perpendicular-toH^{\perp}. Thus, after performing a change of variable ğ—t:=ğ—t+ğ—tassignsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{v}_{t}:=\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{u}_{t} and exploiting the linearity of ğ–¯Hsubscriptğ–¯ğ»\mathsf{P}_{H}, we obtain exactly FedPi:

ğ—t+1=ğ—t+2â€‹ğ—t+1âˆ’ğ—“t+1=ğ—tâˆ’ğ–¯Hâ€‹ğ—t+2â€‹ğ–¯Hâ€‹ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·â€‹ğ—tâˆ’ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·â€‹ğ—t=ğ—t+ğ–±Hâ€‹ğ–±ğ–¿Î·â€‹ğ—t2.subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡2subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ–¯ğ»subscriptğ—ğ‘¡2subscriptğ–¯ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿ğœ‚subscriptğ—ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿ğœ‚subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ–±ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿ğœ‚subscriptğ—ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathsf{v}_{t+1}=\mathsf{u}_{t}+2\mathsf{w}_{t+1}-\mathsf{z}_{t+1}=\mathsf{v}_{t}-\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{v}_{t}+2\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{v}_{t}-\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{v}_{t}=\tfrac{\mathsf{v}_{t}+\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{v}_{t}}{2}. (20)

Comparing (12) and (17)-(18) it is clear that FedProx corresponds to fixing the dual variable ğ—ğ—\mathsf{u} to the constant ğŸ0\mathbf{0} in FedPi. We remark that step (17) is done at the usersâ€™ side while steps (18) and (19) are implemented at the server side. There is no communication overhead either, as the server need only communicate the sum ğ—t+ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{u}_{t} to the respective users while the users need only communicate their ğ³t,isubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘–\mathbf{z}_{t,i} to the server. The dual variable ğ—ğ—\mathsf{u} is kept entirely at the serverâ€™s expense.

Let us point out another subtle difference that may prove useful in FL: FedAvg and FedProx are inherently â€œsynchronousâ€ algorithms, in the sense that all participating users start from a common, averaged model at the beginning of each communication round. In contrast, the local models ğ—“tsubscriptğ—“ğ‘¡\mathsf{z}_{t} in FedPi may be different from each other, where we â€œcorrectâ€ the common, average model ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{w}_{t} with user-specific dual variables ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{u}_{t}. This opens the possibility to personalization by designating the dual variable ğ—ğ—\mathsf{u} in user-specific ways.

Lastly, we remark that in FedProx we need the step size Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} to diminish in order to converge to a solution of the original problem (1) whereas FedPi achieves the same with a constant step size Î·ğœ‚\eta, although at the cost of doubling the memory cost at the server side.

3.5 FedRP as Reflection-Projection splitting

Examining the updates in (9), (12) and (15), we are naturally led to the following further variants (that have not been tried in FL to the best of our knowledge):

ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =ğ–±Hâ€‹ğ–¦ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹ğ—tabsentsubscriptğ–±ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t} (21)
ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =ğ–±Hâ€‹ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹ğ—tabsentsubscriptğ–±ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t} (22)
FedRP:ğ—t+1\displaystyle\mbox{{FedRP}}:\qquad\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =ğ–¯Hâ€‹ğ–±ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹ğ—t.absentsubscriptğ–¯ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}. (23)

Interestingly, the last variant in (23), which we call FedRP, has been studied by [39] under the assumption that ğ–¿=Î¹ğ–ªğ–¿subscriptğœ„ğ–ª\mathsf{f}=\iota_{\mathsf{K}} is an indicator function of an obtuse777Recall that a convex cone ğ–ªğ–ª\mathsf{K} is obtuse iff its dual cone ğ–ªâˆ—:={ğ°âˆ—:âŸ¨ğ°,ğ°âˆ—âŸ©â‰¥0}assignsuperscriptğ–ªconditional-setsuperscriptğ°ğ°superscriptğ°0\mathsf{K}^{*}:=\{\mathbf{w}^{*}:\left\langle\mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rangle\geq 0\} is contained in itself. convex cone ğ–ªğ–ª\mathsf{K}. We prove the following result for FedRP:

Theorem 7.

Let each user participate in every round and the functions {fi}subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\{f_{i}\} be convex. If the step size Î·tâ‰¡Î·subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‚\eta_{t}\equiv\eta is constant, then any fixed point of FedRP is a solution of the regularized problem (13). If the reflector ğ–±ğ–¿Î·superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿ğœ‚\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta} is idempotent (i.e. ğ–±ğ–¿Î·â€‹ğ–±ğ–¿Î·=ğ–±ğ–¿Î·superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ–±ğ–¿ğœ‚\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}=\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}) and the users are homogeneous, then the vanilla iterates ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{w}_{t} of FedRP converge.

It follows easily from a result in [39] that a convex cone is obtuse iff its reflector is idempotent, and hence TheoremÂ 7 strictly extends their result. We remark that TheoremÂ 7 does not apply to the variants (21) and (22) since the reflector ğ–±Hsubscriptğ–±ğ»\mathsf{R}_{H} is not idempotent (recall Hğ»H is defined in (4)). Of course, we can prove (linear) convergence of both variants (21) and (22) if ğ–¿ğ–¿\mathsf{f} is strongly convex. We omit the formal statement and proof since strong convexity does not appear to be easily satisfiable in practice.

In FigureÂ 4, we compare the performance of different splitting algorithms and how they respond to different degrees of user heterogeneity. We use least squares and a CNN model on MNIST for the convex and noconvex experiments, respectively. The details of the experimental setup are described in SectionÂ A.1. For the convex setting, as expected, FedSplit, FedPi, and FedAvg with k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 achieve the smallest optimality gaps. The performance of all the algorithms deteriorates as usersâ€™ data become more heterogeneous (see SectionÂ A.1). For the nonconvex setting, the best results can be achieved by FedRP and FedAvg with a big kğ‘˜k. It is noteworthy that in the nonconvex setting, the performance of FedAvg with k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 is significantly worse than that with k=100ğ‘˜100k=100.

4 Unification, implementation and acceleration

The operator splitting view of FL not only allows us to compare and understand the many existing FL algorithms but also opens the door for unifying and accelerating them. In this section we first introduce a grand scheme that unifies all aforementioned FL algorithms. Then, we provide two implementation variants that can accommodate different hardware and network constraints. Lastly, we explain how to adapt Anderson acceleration [40] to the unified FL algorithm, with almost no computation or communication overhead.

Unification.

We introduce the following grand scheme:

ğ—“t+1subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{z}_{t+1} =(1âˆ’Î±t)â€‹ğ—t+Î±tâ€‹ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·tâ€‹(ğ—t)absent1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡\displaystyle=(1-\alpha_{t})\mathsf{u}_{t}+\alpha_{t}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}(\mathsf{u}_{t}) (24)
ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =(1âˆ’Î²t)â€‹ğ—“t+1+Î²tâ€‹ğ–¯Hâ€‹(ğ—“t+1)absent1subscriptğ›½ğ‘¡subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1subscriptğ›½ğ‘¡subscriptğ–¯ğ»subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1\displaystyle=(1-\beta_{t})\mathsf{z}_{t+1}+\beta_{t}\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}) (25)
ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathsf{u}_{t+1} =(1âˆ’Î³t)â€‹ğ—t+Î³tâ€‹ğ—t+1.absent1subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\displaystyle=(1-\gamma_{t})\mathsf{u}_{t}+\gamma_{t}\mathsf{w}_{t+1}. (26)

TableÂ 1 confirms that the FL algorithms discussed in SectionÂ 3 are all special cases of this unifying scheme, which not only provides new (adaptive) variants but also clearly reveals the similarities and differences between seemingly different algorithms. It may thus be possible to transfer progress on one algorithm to the others and vice versa. We studied the effect of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Î²ğ›½\beta and Î³ğ›¾\gamma and found that Î³ğ›¾\gamma mostly affects the convergence speed: the closer Î³ğ›¾\gamma is to 1, the faster the convergence is, while Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta mostly determine the final optimality gap: the closer they are both to 2 (as in FedSplit and FedPi), the considerably smaller the final optimality gap is. However, setting only one of them close to 2 only has a minor effect on optimality gap or convergence speed.

Implementation.

Interestingly, we also have two implementation possibilities:

  • â€¢

    decentralized: In this variant, all updates in (24)-(26) are computed and stored locally at each user while the server only acts as a bridge for synchronization: it receives ğ³t+1,isubscriptğ³ğ‘¡1ğ‘–\mathbf{z}_{t+1,i} from the iğ‘–i-th user and returns the (same) averaged model ğ–¯Hâ€‹(ğ—“t+1)subscriptğ–¯ğ»subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}) to all users. In a network where users communicate directly with each other, we may then dispense the server and become fully decentralized.

  • â€¢

    centralized: In this variant, the iğ‘–i-th user only stores ğ®t,isubscriptğ®ğ‘¡ğ‘–\mathbf{u}_{t,i} and is responsible for computing and communicating ğ–¯fiÎ·tâ€‹(ğ®t,i)superscriptsubscriptğ–¯subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ®ğ‘¡ğ‘–\mathsf{P}_{f_{i}}^{\eta_{t}}(\mathbf{u}_{t,i}) to the server. In return, the server performs the rest of (24)-(26) and then sends (different) ğ®t+1,isubscriptğ®ğ‘¡1ğ‘–\mathbf{u}_{t+1,i} back to the iğ‘–i-th user.

The two variants are of course mathematically equivalent in their basic form. However, as we see below, they lead to different acceleration techniques and we may prefer one over the other depending on the hardware and network constraints.

Acceleration.

Let us abstract the grand scheme (24)-(26) as the map ğ—t+1=ğ–³ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ–³ğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{u}_{t+1}=\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t}, where ğ–³ğ–³\mathsf{T} is nonexpansive if ğ–¿ğ–¿\mathsf{f} is convex and Î±t,Î²tâˆˆ[0,2],Î³tâˆˆ[0,1]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½ğ‘¡02subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡01\alpha_{t},\beta_{t}\in[0,2],\gamma_{t}\in[0,1]. Following [41], we may then apply the Anderson type-II acceleration to furthur improve convergence. Let U=[ğ—tâˆ’Ï„,â€¦,ğ—t]ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡ğœâ€¦subscriptğ—ğ‘¡U=[\mathsf{u}_{t-\tau},\ldots,\mathsf{u}_{t}] be given along with T=[ğ–³ğ—tâˆ’Ï„,â€¦,ğ–³ğ—t]ğ‘‡subscriptğ–³ğ—ğ‘¡ğœâ€¦subscriptğ–³ğ—ğ‘¡T=[\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t-\tau},\ldots,\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t}]. We solve the following simple least-squares problem:

ğ…âˆ—=argminğ…âŠ¤â€‹ğŸ=1{â€–(Uâˆ’T)â€‹ğ…â€–22}=Gâ€ â€‹ğŸğŸâŠ¤â€‹Gâ€ â€‹ğŸ,whereG=(Uâˆ’T)âŠ¤â€‹(Uâˆ’T).formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ…subscriptargminsuperscriptğ…top11superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘ˆğ‘‡ğ…22superscriptğºâ€ 1superscript1topsuperscriptğºâ€ 1whereğºsuperscriptğ‘ˆğ‘‡topğ‘ˆğ‘‡\displaystyle\bm{\pi}^{*}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\bm{\pi}^{\top}\mathbf{1}=1}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \{\|(U-T)\bm{\pi}\|_{2}^{2}\}=\tfrac{G^{\dagger}\mathbf{1}}{\mathbf{1}^{\top}G^{\dagger}\mathbf{1}},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathrm{where}\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ G=(U-T)^{\top}(U-T). (27)

(For simplicity we do not require ğ…ğ…\bm{\pi} to be nonnegative.) Then, we update ğ—t+1=Tâ€‹ğ…âˆ—subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptğ…\mathsf{u}_{t+1}=T\bm{\pi}^{*}. Clearly, when Ï„=0ğœ0\tau=0, (trivially) Ï€âˆ—=1superscriptğœ‹1\pi^{*}=1 and we reduce to ğ—t+1=ğ–³ğ—tsubscriptğ—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ–³ğ—ğ‘¡\mathsf{u}_{t+1}=\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t}. With a larger memory size Ï„ğœ\tau, we may significantly improve convergence. Importantly, all heavy lifting (computation and storage) is done at the server side and we do not increase communication at all. We note that the same acceleration can also be applied on each user for computing ğ–¯ğ–¿Î·tsuperscriptsubscriptğ–¯ğ–¿subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}, if the users can afford the memory cost.

We have already seen how different variants (e.g. FedAvg, FedProx, FedSplit, FedPi, FedRP) compare to each other in Â§3. We performed further experiments to illustrate their behaviour under Anderson acceleration. (See AppendixÂ A for details on our experimental setup.) As can be observed in FigureÂ 5, Anderson acceleration helps FL algorithms converge considerably faster, all without incurring any overhead. For the convex models (least squares and logistic regression), our implementation of Anderson-acceleration speeds up all of the algorithms, especially FedAvg, FedProx and FedRP. However, for the nonconvex CNN model, it is beneficial only for FedAvg, FedProx and FedPi, while applying it to FedRP and FedSplit makes them unstable. It is noteworthy that we already know FedProx and FedPi are more stable than FedRP and FedSplit, respectively, and hence it makes intuitive sense that acceleration improves the two more stable algorithms. Another important point we wish to point out is that our acceleration method does not affect the quality of the algorithmsâ€™ final solutions, but rather it just accelerates their convergence.

5 Conclusions

We have connected FL with the established theory of operator splitting, revealed new insights on existing algorithms and suggested new algorithmic variants and analysis. Our unified view makes it easy to understand, compare, implement and accelerate different FL algorithms in a streamlined and standardized fashion. Our experiments demonstrate some interesting differences in the convex and nonconvex settings, and in the early and late communication rounds. In the future we plan to study the effect of stochasticity and extend our analysis to nonconvex functions. While our initial experiments confirmed the potential of Anderson-acceleration for FL, further work is required to formalize its effect in theory (such as [58]) and to understand its relation with other momentum methods in FL.

Data heterogeneity measure:

We adopt the data heterogeneity measure of [11], and quantify the amount of heterogeneity in usersâ€™ data for the least squares and logistic regression problems by

H:=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â€–22,assignğ»1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ°22\displaystyle H:=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\parallel\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{*})\parallel_{2}^{2},

where ğ°âˆ—subscriptğ°\mathbf{w}_{*} is a minimizer of the original problem (1). When usersâ€™ data is homogeneous, all the local functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} have the same minimizer of ğ°âˆ—subscriptğ°\mathbf{w}_{*} and H=0ğ»0H=0. In general, the more heterogeneous the usersâ€™ data is, the larger Hğ»H becomes.

Other parameters:

Throughout the experiments, we use local learning rate Î·=10âˆ’5ğœ‚superscript105\eta=10^{-5} for least squares, and Î·=10âˆ’2ğœ‚superscript102\eta=10^{-2} for logistic regression, and run FedAvg with k=5ğ‘˜5k=5 for both least squares and logistic regression, unless otherwise specified. In FigureÂ 5, FedAvg is run with k=2ğ‘˜2k=2.

A.2 Experimental setup: MNIST datasets

We consider a distributed setting with 202020 users. In order to create a non-i.i.d. dataset, we follow a similar procedure as in [1]: first we split the data from each class into several shards. Then, each user is randomly assigned a number of shards of data. For example, in FigureÂ 4 to guarantees that no user receives data from more than 666 classes, we split each class of MNIST into 121212 shards (i.e., a total of 120120120 shards for the whole dataset), and each user is randomly assigned 666 shards of data. By considering 202020 users, this procedure guarantees that no user receives data from more than 666 classes and the data distribution of each user is different from each other. The local datasets are balancedâ€“all users have the same amount of training samples. The local data is split into train, validation, and test sets with percentage of 808080%, 101010%, and 101010%, respectively. In this way, each user has 240024002400 data points for training, 300300300 for test, and 300300300 for validation. We use a simple 2-layer CNN model with ReLU activation, the detail of which can be found in TableÂ 2. To update the local models at each user using its local data, unless otherwise is stated, we apply gradient descent with Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 for FedAvg, and gradient descent with k=100ğ‘˜100k=100 and Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 for proximal update in the splitting algorithms.

A.3 Experimental setup: CIFAR-10 dataset

We consider a distributed setting with 101010 users, and use a sub-sampled CIFAR-10 dataset, which is 20%percent2020\% of the training set. In order to create a non-i.i.d. dataset, we follow a similar procedure as in [1]: first we sort all data points according to their classes. Then, they are split into 100100100 shards, and each user is randomly assigned 101010 shards of data. The local data is split into train, validation, and test sets with percentage of 808080%, 101010%, and 101010%, respectively. In this way, each user has 800800800 data points for training, 100100100 for test, and 100100100 for validation. We use a 2-layer CNN model on the dataset, , the detail of which can be found in TableÂ 3. To update the local models at each user using its local data, we apply stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with local batch size B=20ğµ20B=20 and local learning rate Î·=0.1ğœ‚0.1\eta=0.1. All users participate in each communication round.

Appendix B Full experiments

In this section we provide more experimental results that are deferred from the main paper.

B.1 FedRP experiments to supplement Figure 2

In FigureÂ 6, we show the effect of step size Î·ğœ‚\eta on the convergence of FedRP on least squares and logistic regression. We run FedRP with both fixed and diminishing step sizes. In the experiments with diminishing step sizes, we set the initial value of Î·ğœ‚\eta (i.e. Î·0subscriptğœ‚0\eta_{0}) to larger valuesâ€“compared to the constant Î·ğœ‚\eta valuesâ€“to ensure that Î·ğœ‚\eta does not get very small after the first few rounds. From the figure, one can see that FedRP with a fixed learning rate converges faster in early stage but to a sub-optimal solution. In contrast, FedRP with diminishing Î·ğœ‚\eta converges slower early, but to better final solutions. It is interesting to note that the convergence behaviour of FedRP is similar to that of FedProx and when the conditions of TheoremÂ 2 are satisfied, FedRP converges to a correct solution of the original problem (1), e.g. see the results for Î·tâˆ1/tproportional-tosubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡\eta_{t}\propto 1/t which satisfies both conditions in TheoremÂ 2. Moreover, one can see that ergodic averaging hardly affects the convergence of FedRP in the following results.

B.2 Effect of changing kğ‘˜k or Î·ğœ‚\eta for FedAvg

In FigureÂ 7, we observe a trade-off between faster (early) convergence and better final solution when varying local epochs kğ‘˜k or learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta, in least squares and logistic regression experiments. When Î·ğœ‚\eta is fixed, larger local epochs kğ‘˜k leads to faster convergence (in terms of communication rounds) during the early stages, at the cost of a worse final solution. When local epochs kğ‘˜k is fixed, same trade-off holds true for increasing Î·ğœ‚\eta.

In FigureÂ 8, contrary to what we observe in the previous convex experiments where fixed learning rate with less local epochs leads to a better final solution at the expense of slower convergence, we do not see similar trade-offs in this nonconvex setting, (at least) given the computation we can afford. This is probably because the solution we get is still in early stage due to the combined complexity of CNN and CIFAR-10 dataset, compared to the relatively simple least squares and logistic regression we had before.

B.3 Effect of user sampling

The grand scheme introduced in (24)-(26) assumes that all users participate in each communication roundâ€“full user participation; however, this might not be always the case. So, we modify the grand scheme to investigate the effect of user participation. The modified version, which is based on the centralized implementation of FL algorithms (explained in sectionÂ 4), is given in Algorithm 1. The simulation results for least squares and logistic regression are shown in FigureÂ 9. From the results it can be observed that, with partial user participation, none of the aforementioned algorithms converge to the correct solution, especially FedAvg with k=1ğ‘˜1k=1. Also, FedSplit becomes unstable when user participation is low (p=0.5ğ‘0.5p=0.5), while other algorithms e.g. FedPi remain stable.

B.4 Effect of using mini-batch gradient descent locally

FigureÂ 10 shows the results when each user uses mini-batch gradient descent to update its model for different splitting algorithms. As in the grand scheme (24)-(26), we assume full user participation. Algorithm 2 summarizes the implementation details. As can be observed in the convex setting experiments, with mini-batch gradient descent used locally, none of the aforementioned algorithms converge to the correct solution. Furthermore, convergence speed of the algorithms decreases compared to when users use standard gradient descent. Also, FedAvg, even with k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, does not outperform the other splitting algorithms, and FedSplit and FedPi converge to better solutions. On the other hand, in the nonconvex setting, FedAvg with k=100ğ‘˜100k=100 achieves better solutions compared to the other algorithms.

B.5 Results with error bars: FigureÂ 1, Left

To avoid clutter, we did not present the error bars in FigureÂ 2 but report them here. The yğ‘¦y-axis represents the training loss {fâ€‹(ğ°FedAvgâˆ—)}ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ°FedAvg\{f(\mathbf{w}_{\texttt{FedAvg}}^{*})\} of (approximate) fixed-point solutions of FedAvg for different learning rates Î·ğœ‚\eta and local epochs kğ‘˜k, and the shaded area illustrates the maximum and minimum over 4 different runs.

Implementation details of Anderson acceleration for nonconvex CNN:

In practice, we found that applying the acceleration algorithm to ğ–¯Hâ€‹(ğ—“t+1)subscriptğ–¯ğ»subscriptğ—“ğ‘¡1\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}) in (25) rather than ğ—t+1subscriptğ—ğ‘¡1\mathsf{u}_{t+1} in (26) leads to a more stable algorithm. FedRP and FedSplit are less stable and Anderson acceleration actually made them worse while FedAvg, FedProx and FedPi converge much faster with our implementation of Anderson acceleration.
